chapters.title: The Procrastination Diagnosis: It's Not Laziness, It's Weakness
chapters.summary: Introduces the core premise: procrastination as a weakness of the 'initiation muscle' rather than a moral failing. Readers perform a self-assessment to identify their specific 'weak spots' (e.g., starting, switching, sustaining).
key_events: Debunking the 'lazy' myth with neuroscience of task initiation.
The Procrastination Muscle Map: Identifying your personal weak points.
First 'rep': The 5-Minute Couch Test (simply getting up and sitting down at your work station).
chapters.ending_hook: You've diagnosed the weakness. Now, the training begins. Tomorrow, you'll perform your first real rep to strengthen the most fundamental muscle of all: The Start.

chapters.title: The First Rep: Priming the Start Muscle
chapters.summary: Focuses on the most basic muscle: initiating any action. Exercises are designed to be absurdly easy, breaking the paralysis of the 'first step' by making it trivial and non-threatening.
key_events: The 'One-Touch' Rule: Making contact with a task without the pressure to continue.
Exercise: The Two-Minute Crank (starting a timer and doing ANYTHING related to a task for 120 seconds).
Understanding the 'activation energy' required for tasks and how to lower it.
chapters.ending_hook: You've proven you can start anything for two minutes. But what happens when the timer stops? Next, we build the muscle to bridge that gap.

chapters.title: Building the Bridge: From Initiation to Momentum
chapters.summary: Trains the 'continuity muscle' to carry the energy from a tiny start into a sustainable flow, preventing the classic 'start-and-stop' pattern.
key_events: The concept of 'micro-momentum' and how to capture it.
Exercise: The '+1 Rule' (after your 2-minute crank, do just one more tiny, defined action).
Creating 'ritual bridges' that seamlessly connect starting to doing.
chapters.ending_hook: Momentum is now a conscious practice, not luck. But momentum crashes into distractions. Time to fortify your focus against interruption.

chapters.title: Fortifying Focus: The Distraction Deadlift
chapters.summary: Strengthens the mental muscle to resist and manage distractions. Focus is treated as a strength to be exerted, not a passive state.
key_events: Reframing distractions as 'focus weights' to be lifted.
Exercise: The Intentional Interruption (scheduling a distraction, then consciously resisting it for a short period).
Building a 'focus perimeter' using environmental design and the 'phone face-down' rep.
chapters.ending_hook: You can now deadlift a notification. But what about the heavy weight of a task you genuinely dread? Next chapter: the heavy lifting.

chapters.title: Heavy Lifting: Conquering the Dreaded Task
chapters.summary: Applies strength-training principles (like spotting and progressive overload) to the most intimidating items on your to-do list.
key_events: The 'Spotter' Technique: Breaking a dreadful task into spotted components.
Exercise: The Ugly First Draft Sprint (5 minutes of intentionally bad work on the scary thing).
Progressive Overload for tasks: gradually increasing the 'weight' of engagement.
chapters.ending_hook: The monster task has been touched. But a strong body isn't just about heavy lifts—it needs balance. It's time to train your rest muscle.

chapters.title: The Strategic Rest: Training the Recovery Muscle
chapters.summary: Challenges the guilt around breaks. Teaches how to take intentional, restorative pauses that recharge willpower instead of depleting it into procrastination.
key_events: Differentiating procrastination (avoidance) from strategic rest (replenishment).
Exercise: The Set-Point Reset (a strict 5-minute non-screen, non-task mental reset).
Scheduling 'rest reps' into your daily regimen to prevent willpower fatigue.
chapters.ending_hook: Rest is now part of the workout, not a failure. With a balanced regimen, we can now tackle the complex obstacle course of a real-world project.

chapters.title: The Obstacle Course: Managing Multi-Step Projects
chapters.summary: Trains coordination between different mental muscles (starting, switching, sustaining) to navigate complex projects without burning out or getting lost.
key_events: The 'Project Pyramid' method: building projects from stable, small reps upward.
Exercise: The Next-Handhold Drill (spending 5 minutes identifying and executing ONLY the very next physical action).
Implementing 'circuit training' for projects: rotating between different sub-tasks.
chapters.ending_hook: Projects are now just a series of familiar reps. But what happens when your environment is toxic to your gains? Time to audit your gym.

chapters.title: Environmental Design: Crafting Your Willpower Gym
chapters.summary: Readers learn to engineer their physical and digital spaces to reduce friction for good decisions and increase friction for procrastination, making willpower the default.
key_events: The 'Friction Audit' for workspaces and devices.
Exercise: The Sunday System Shutdown (a weekly 5-minute ritual to reset default apps, clear physical clutter, and set up 'easy paths' for the week).
Creating 'motivation tunnels' where the desired action is the path of least resistance.
chapters.ending_hook: Your environment now works for you, not against you. But a true athlete also needs the right fuel. Let's examine your mental nutrition.

chapters.title: Mental Nutrition: Fueling the Willpower Engine
chapters.summary: Explores the cognitive and emotional 'diet' that drains or sustains willpower, including self-talk, media consumption, and the stories we tell ourselves about our work.
key_events: Identifying 'willpower junk food' (doomscrolling, negative self-talk).
Exercise: The Reframe Rep (catching a negative thought and spending 5 minutes writing a factual, neutral alternative).
Consuming 'willpower superfoods' like small wins, inspiration, and positive peer examples.
chapters.ending_hook: You're now fueling your mind for performance. But even the best athletes face setbacks. Next: building resilience for the inevitable fail.

chapters.title: Failure as a Rep: Building Resilience
chapters.summary: Reframes missed days, setbacks, and relapses as essential 'eccentric training' that ultimately builds stronger mental toughness and recovery.
key_events: The 'PR' (Personal Record) of Failure: tracking and learning from lapses.
Exercise: The Post-Failure Autopsy (a structured 5-minute journaling to analyze a procrastination episode without judgment).
The 'Bounce-Back' Ritual: a quick sequence to re-engage after a fall.
chapters.ending_hook: Setbacks are now data, not defeat. You're becoming antifragile. It's time to step back and design your own lifelong maintenance plan.

chapters.title: Designing Your Maintenance Regimen
chapters.summary: Guides the reader to create a personalized, sustainable 'mental fitness' plan using the exercises they've mastered, moving beyond the 90-day program.
key_events: How to conduct a weekly 'mental muscle check-in'.
Building a hybrid routine: mixing 'strength' (challenge) reps with 'maintenance' (easy) reps.
Identifying 'plateau' signs and how to adjust your regimen for continued growth.
chapters.ending_hook: You are now the coach of your own will. You have the plan. The final chapter is about stepping onto the platform and seeing yourself in a new light.

chapters.title: The New Identity: You Are a Person Who Acts
chapters.summary: Cementing the identity shift from 'procrastinator' to 'someone with strong initiation muscles.' Focuses on celebrating the new default behaviors and looking to the future.
key_events: Reviewing the 'before and after' of your Procrastination Muscle Map.
The story you tell yourself: rewriting your internal narrative from 'I struggle with' to 'I am good at'.
Final Exercise: The Legacy Rep (5 minutes envisioning a future project and feeling the confidence of knowing you have the tools to tackle it).
chapters.ending_hook: The gym doors are open. Your will is stronger. The world is full of tasks waiting to be lifted. Go lift them.
